Entry.1: As usual in camp, and a sports meeting amongA.C.F.A. held.
Entry.3:
March to Rafa Station. Blankets etc put through fumigating train. Saw Turkish prisoners just from Jerusalem being put through phenyle bath, etc. Prisoners of war also fillling in trenches.

Parcel from home.
Entry.4: Printed photos and wrote a letter.
Entry.5:
A.C.F.A. Soccer football team played Scottish Machine Gunners. A good game. Scores – 2 to 4 goals.

Parcel from home.
Entry.6: Nothing unusual. A gas parade with the new Box Respirators.
Entry.7:
A further advance on the front line reported Rumored that Referendum has been defeated by 173,000. Attempted some mending.

A party was given to the M.Grs.
Entry.11: Things as usual. Prospects of leave.
Entry.12: Published that leave is to be given to Cairo and Alexandria.
Entry.13:
As usual.2 go on leave. 
Wrote
 4 letters received.
Entry.15: Usual routine. 4th Battn beat A.C.F.A. at football.
Entry.16:
January 1918

Another 
one
 goes on leave.
Entry.18:
A.C.F.A. beaten at Rugby.

Wrote letters on several of these days.

Market started in Rafa. (A wash out.)
Entry.19: As usual with the exception of another mail as late as Dec 17 - 1917.
Entry.20:
Wrote letters.

1 more goes on leave. I am 22nd on list for leave.

Issued with overseacolors.

Monday 21
Entry.21:
Several parades extra on account of inspection by Brig. Gen Smith V.C. and Major Gen. Sir W. H.Chauvel K.C.M.G. C.B.

Wrote a letter again.
Entry.22:
Did a little sewing by way of a change today.

Sewed colors on
new
tunic.
Entry.23:
Fixing saddles and have been allotted new camel.

News of "Goeben" and "Breslau"

Recreation Hut in course of erection closeby for use of this Brigade.
Entry.24:
5 Courts Martial
s
 held today at B.H.Q'rs. Saddlery again.
Entry.25:
A wet day and nothing much doing.

Saturday 26
Entry.26: One more goes on leave tonight.
Entry.27: Parades increasing every day, much to the "pleasure" of "some".
Entry.28:
Parades reaching a ridicule now.

Very changeable weather.Port Said leave begins on 2nd Feb.
Entry.29:
Finer weather today. Wrote a letter.

Recreation Hut being improved.
Entry.30:
To be inspected tomorrow by the Brig-Gen of our Brigade.

Concert tonight in Recreation Hut; for 1st Battn.Vernon's concert party.
Entry.31:
Inspected by the Brig– Faults found in the various places throughout the Ambulance lines.

He spoke to me about having my hair "
long
" as 
he
 termed it. Result haircut.

Word of change of our Regl. colors and of the other
s
 troops in Palestine and Egypt. Wrote home.
Entry.32:
Football again;otherwise nothing unusual.

Concert in Recreation Hut tonight.
Entry.33:
Nothing out of the ordinary. Signs of being here longer than we anticipated.

Concert again tonight.
Entry.34:
Went to Chruch Parade. Unusual for me.

2 letters from Australia dated Dec. 23rd & 24th 1917.

Football again.
Entry.38:
A miserable day.

(A fountain pen at last.)

Watched a Rugby match of A.C.F.A. & 1st Battn teams.

Our team beaten again.

"Mounted gas parade"
Entry.39:
February 1918

A wet miserable day. Finished a letter.
Entry.40:
Another miserable day. Wrote home.

A.C.F.A. Soccer team win against European 
team
 staff of Hong-Kong & Singapore Batty.

Sunday 10
Entry.41:
Weather as bad as ever. No church parade.

A.C.F.A arrrange program for concert on night of sports and practise for same.

1st crime in A.C.F.A. on A:S occurred this morning.
Entry.42:
Sports postponed till 18th & 19th inst.

A.C.F.A. Rugby team score a win against 2nd Battn. of our Bgde. Wrote letters
Entry.43:
A finer day today. Cinema pictures taken of the Bgde, for compilation of war records.

Wrote a letter.
Entry.44: Things as usual. 2 go on leave to Cairo.
Entry.45:
As usual. 3 go on leave to Port Said Rest Camp.

(C. Berry leaves for down the line.)
Entry.46:
February 1918

Camels inspected by the Brig.

2 more reinfts.for Ambulance.
Entry.51:
Routine as usual.

Turkish ammtn,dump blown up.
Entry.53: 2 more go on leave to Alexandria.
Entry.57:
Rumors prevalent. (Latest to move on Friday)

3 return from Pt Said & 3 more go on leave to same place.
Entry.58:
Port Said
 Preparing for move in a couple of days.
Entry.60:
as yesterday.

Australian mail to hand this afternoon at last. Great satisfacton,

Wrote 1 letter
s
tonight.
Entry.61:
Cleaning up preparatory to moving out tomorrow at 10.30 a.m.

Advance party leave at 10.30 a.m. today
Entry.62: March 12 miles to Shelal and led our camels with full gear on. Arrived at Shelal at 5 p.m.
Entry.63: No church parade. Getting things fixed in our new camp site at Shelal. East side of Rly station. Country looking beautiful with the grass and self sown crops.
Entry.64:
A Section go out on 16 mile stunt and ½ of the Battalions do likewise.

2 letters written.
Entry.65:
B Section go out on the 16 mile stunt.

1 letter written.
Entry.68:
March 1918

B Section go out on all day stunt.
Entry.69:
Given the chance of 10 days leave to Port Said this morning. Accepted it and got ready. At 4 p.m. on account of urgent movement orders leave cancelled.

(Had written to Joy & home but have "slipped" for leave.)
Entry.70: Moved off at 2 p.m and travelled to Heria.
Entry.71:
Moved off at 5.30 a.m.

Reached Julis at 5.30 p.m.

Accident with aerial torpedo. 1 native and 2 camels killed.
Entry.72:
"Jacko" visited us
.

Moved off at 6.15 a.m.

Arrived Dieran 7.30 pm.

Picquet from 10 pm to 12 
p
midnight
Entry.73:
In bivouac.

"Jacko" visited us.

Monitors seem busy on the coast.

Australian mail dated 29th Jan to hand. Wrote to Joy.
Entry.74:
Met some of the old boys.

"Jacko" visited us this morning.
Entry.75:
During afternoon Geor C- & I went to Dieran. Had a 
hot bath
the first (hot bath) since leaving Australia 10 months ago.

Bought 2 souvenirs of pictures & flowers of the Holy Land.

Uncertain weather. Rain and wind setting in.
Entry.76:
Wet & miserable weather today. Wrote a note home.

Expect
 to be on the move towards Jerusalem tomorrow at 10 pm.

Raining heavily.
Entry.78:
Saddle up at 9.15 a.m. Moved off from Dieran in the rain at 10 am. Travelled through till 1 p.m.

½ hr. for lunch. On again till 3 pm. through fields which were cultivated before the rains started lately. Mud terrific. Camels hardly able to move in it at all. Caught up to H.K. & S'pore Batty. here Junction Station and had to wait 2 hrs or more to cross a wad
dy
i in flood. (in single file.)

On the move till 10 pm. when the country got very 
h
 mountainous and we gotbogged. Messenger went to B.H.Qrs. and we turned in after something to eat at midnight or thereabouts.

Monday 18 March 1918

Rained in early morning & when the order came at 4.45 a.m. to saddle up the thought of what was in store for us made me sick at the thought of it. Moved off at 5.30 a.m. travelling in single file.

Country very mountainous and almost impassable on acct. of the mud. ¾ hr. for breakfast, some time of which was spent in picking wild flowers of which there was an abundance of various kinds. Halted at 2 pm for an hrs. lunch.

Off again and travelled through till 7 pm.

From 2 pm. till 7 pm. passed through valleys and over mountains by a rough track with stones banked on either side. We must now be 12 to 14 hundred feet above sea level & the view at dusk was great.

Today I took a snap of the spot where David fought Goliath. An ancient well at Zakariza was examined. Country very picturesque but cold.
Entry.79:
Saddle up at 5.30 a.m. Travelled till 9 a.m. 40 mins halt for breakfast. 
Next halt at Solomons Pool where there is a monastery solidly built
.

Next halt for 10 mins at 10.30 a.m at St George"s Convent (Lesjar) on the sight of an old Gr. monastery. Passed through an archway, the entrance to Solomons Well (at which 2 hrs. later our water fantasies were filled.)

Went into bivouac at 12 noon in the hills in sight of Bethlehem which is 1½miles from the bivouac area.
Entry.80:
No move apparently today.

At 10.30 a.m. went for a walkto Solomon's Pools of which there are 3. Took 2 snaps. Followed a well made road along the side of a steep walled valley and in 
h
 20 mins. reached a beautiful monastery built in recent years.

On opposite side of valley are old Roman ruins and 1 mile further on walls of the fortifications of the Crusaders.

Close to Solomons Pools is a Crusaders Castle – the ruins of same. Had a look through same.

Bethlehem leave.
Entry.81:
In bivouac today till 5 pm. when we saddledup and at dark an hr orso later moved along the Bethlehem - Jerusalem road (which is now dry)

At 8 pm. we passed through Bethlehem and at 11.15 through Jerusalem. Bright moonlight.

Midnight found us still in the saddle.
Entry.82:
On the march past Jerusalem and at daybreak bivouaced in the 
hills
 mountains 5 to 6 miles the other side off the main Jerusalem - Jericho road.

All day here and turned in early in evening to make up for last nights lost sleep.
Entry.83:
Watered camels at a pumping station in the mountains ½ mile past an old Roman wall – a pass in the Jerusalem and Jericho mountains.

Back from watering at 5.30 pm. (Left forwatering 11 am.) Took 6½ hrs.

About to turn in at 7 pm. when order for saddle up came and by 10.30 p.m. the whole Bgde was on tlhe move on the Jerusalem- Jericho road.

Travelled all night.
Entry.84:
At 4 a.m. we passed Jericho and halted for breakfast at a spot 2 miles away at daybreak. Are now in the Jordan Valley with the Jordan River 5 miles away.

At 3.30 pm. we crossed the Jordan River over a pontoon bridge (Slow travelling on acct. of single file over the bridge.)

Travelled till 5.45 pm. and halted for a snack near a large Arab encampment. These Arabs are all fully armed and mostly mounted.

Moved out at 11 pm. Slow travelled in single file and walking and leading camels on acct. of the very mountainous country.

Mandesi Ford is where we crossed.
Entry.85:
Still on the march. Halted for ½ an hr or so at dawn and then on again. Rain now well set in and road almost impassable in single file.

Travelled till midnight with 2 stops of ½ hr or so for a little to eat.
Entry.86:
Joined up with the Light Horse at dawn after being in the rain all night on the march.

Passed through the village of –halted for 2 hrs. Breakfasted. On again and joined up with the Mounted Troops at–

Had something to eat and turned in after the saddles had been removed at 3 pm. being on practically 72 hrs. and us with no sleep for the same time.

Es Salt fell this morning. Prisoners taken and 19 motor transport wagons captured with some German prisoners.

(Sent F.S. Card with a chap being evacuated (Mar 26th)

Taube machine gunned the section I was with this morning.

Wednesday 27March 1918

Saddle up at8 a.m. and awaited orders.

Moved at 9.30 to the hills in the direction of Amman which is being attacked by our troops (mounted)

2nd Battn I.C.C. Bgde go into line and get cut up with heavy casualties.

Casualties arrive at Clearing Station at 3 pm and continue so right through till midnight.

Light Horse cut Rly line Sth of Ammon and capture an enemy Rly train of ammuntn and stores.

Enemy making a determined stand against Camel Bgde on the main sector.

Rations run out tomorrow morng. We are now out.

Call made by QM for rations to help feed the wounded that cannot be got away.
Entry.87:
Last of casualties arrive at 3 a.m.

1½ hrs sleep tonight. Few arrived after daybreak.

Our position not too safe as one shell came over and all but the Fd Amb led camels have moved back a distance of 1 mile.

Turkish prisoners arrive about 70 in all – well clothed and apparently well fed.

At 3.30 pm heavy artillery action takes place. H.K. & S'pore Batt'ywithdraw and 3 Mountain Howitzer Batties continue

4.30 pm Jacko falls back and all prepare to advance a little at 5.30 p.m.

5.30 pm. No advance made and firing on the line ceases a good deal.

7 p.m. Attending to wounded still arriving while 2 Brigades of Infy move up to the line

In early hrs. of this morning NZ's blew up section of Rly line Nth of Ammon.

2 days rations arrive 8 pm.

No facilities for evacuation of wounded.
Entry.88: Still finds us attending to wounded troops in the battle of Ammon and next to no rest from toil, right through till 6 p.m.
Entry.89:
batches of wounded have been evacuated today.

Dressing station changed over and here we are at 7 p.m. expecting the result of the final push expected to take place tonight on Ammon.

Rain setting in again.

Rumors of reverse in France.
Entry.90:
Turned out at 6 am. and had to make several trips to Divisl Hd Qrs and to dressing Stn. on horseback.

At 10 a.m. packed up and saddled up, and 2 p.m. found us relieving the Advanced Dressin Statn.

Established a Clearing Station but at dusk word of an immediate move back came and 25 mins or so found us on the march back to the position we were in this morning. Arrived there at 9 pm, 
and
 left camels with strip saddles, and turned in.

Cannot fathom this move.

Easter Day
Entry.91:
Turned out at 4.30 am. after being on picquet from 12.20 a.m. till 2 am. and running about with the Div. Hd Qrs despatch messenger till 3.15 am. Saddle up at 5 a.m. and on the move once again.

Travelled slowly till we reached the village of 
Sira
 Ain Sur when the whole I.C.C. Bgde had to 
advance
 retreat in single file, which delayed the whole days travelling. Snapped the village of
Sira
Ain Sur.

Rain set in about dusk and by 8 pm. the mountains were impassable. 3 or 4 sent on to HD QRS report state of affairs of Amb. & Transport.

Rest took loads off saddles and after something to eat turned in.

Infantry passing our bivouac area all night (60th Divn Infty)
Entry.92:
Turned out at dawn and saddled up. On the move at 5.45a.m. walking. Road or rather track over the mountains towards Jordan & its valley is now improving.

Arrived at a camp 6 miles from Jordan at 10 a.m. Issued with 6 days rations and watered camels.

Moved at 2 p.m. and at 4.30 pm. crossed the Jordan River by the pontoon bridge at which engineers are busy constructing 2 
or 3
 such bridges. Took a snap of part of ourAmb. Transpt crossingthis bridge.

Bivouaced at a spot¼ mile from wall of Jericho at 6.30 pm. Had something to eat and turned in tired:

Refugees from Es Salt fleeing to Jerusalem along the Caravan Road from Es Salt - Jericho & Jerusalem. Arabs being disarmed before crossing Jordan.

Practically all troops with the exception of some A.L.H. are over the Jordan on Jericho side at 12 midnight.
Entry.93:
Turned out at 6 am. Breakfasted and order given to saddle up at 7.15 am. when 
8 to 10
 
14
14 enemy planes came over and bombed all the troops in this particular part of the Jordan valley.

2 "Tommies" killed and 10 "Tommies" & Australians wounded as result. At 9 am. A.C.Fd. Amb. moved over in direction of the Mount of Tempation.

Bivouaced here with a good view of the town of Jericho with Dead Sea in 
B
 background. Snapped this with V.P.K.

On A.C.F.A. Brigade Orderly 
for A.C.F.A
. duties.

Australian mail to hand at dusk.

Saddle up at 6.30 p.m. and moved outup the Jordan Valley towards Nablus where we bivouaced in the mountains at 11.45 pm. Unsaddled and lay down to rest till dawn. (We moved 6 miles tonight.)

Took snap of the monastery on the Mount of Temptation.

(Es Salt now in Turks & Germans hands so we hear. How this is we know not
just
 
now
.
Entry.94:
In bivouac 1 mile off the main caravan road.

First thing this morning just at daybreak about a dozen enemy planes came over and although bombed our troops about here did no damage to our Brigade. "Tommy" Clearing Station & horse transpt were hit.

At 9.15 a.m. more mail given out. Among 3 I got was a long one from Joy. Now received my letters dated as late as Dec. 21st 1917. Christmas Cards. (Amb. & Bgde cards.) and "Cacolet" arrived safely.

At 11.30 a.m. started to make a dugout. Finished & had lunch. At 3 p.m. managed to procure a few canteen supplies brought up by A.I.F. Comforts and canteen motor cars.

4 pm. Enemy advancing on opposite side of Jordan and with this and one or two other things expect to have a hot time of it.

On picquet from 6.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m.
Entry.95:
Picquet from 12.30 a.m. to 2.30 a.m. and 6.30 a.m to 8.30 a.m.

Turned out at 6 a.m. from our dugouts.

Groomed & fed up camels.

"Jacko" came over at 8.35 a.m. only observing to our satisfaction this morning

At 10 a.m. went to the wadi for a dip and washed some clothes.

Lunch and then on picquet from 12.30 p.m to 2.30 p.m. Started a letter.

A few shells 
were
 came over but not near out position.

Batty. of 60 pndrs close to us.

At 3.30 pmwent for another dip to wadi. Continued letter from 8 to 8.45 pm and turned in at 9 pm.

1 Sandcart has gone out for wounded. Capt Andrews A.C.F.A. evacted wounded.

One of our scouting planes up all day.

Sent 2 notes and 9 F.S.C'ds away this morning at 9 a.m.

14 of our planes went over to Jacko bombing.
Entry.96:
Turned out at 6 a.m.

Groomed and
Entry.97:
fed up.

Breakfast at 8.15 a.m. "Jacko" over observing at 8.30 a.m. "Antis" shooting rotten.

Nothing much doing on the line today. No casualties coming to our dressing station.

Tonight I finished an 11 page letter to J.W.

12 of our planes went over to "Jacko" bombing.

Had a dip in the stream this afternoon.

Good rations now and plenty of them.

Parade called and praise given for recent operations.

Saturday 6 April 1918

Out at 6 a.m. Stables at 6.15 a.m. Breakfast 7.30 a.m. Grazing camels at 9 a.m.

Started letter.

No enemy planes over yet at 10.15 a.m.

8.30 p.m
. No planes of the enemy over all day.

Wrote 2 letters.

Drew rations at dump.

Fresh meat and brown bread issued.

Another Australian mail expected in tomorrow.
Entry.98:
Out at 6 a.m. as usual.

Grazing picquet from9 to 11 a.m.

Several enemy planes over at different times for obstn purposes only.

A good deal of shrapnel over gun positionsCasualties slight.

Mail expected but none arrived. 2 short letters written.

Fresh meat & bread issued.
Entry.99:
April 1918

Groomed and fed up as usual after 6.15 a.m.

Left at 10.15 a.m. with Geo. for Jericho with 5 natives & 9 camels to draw fresh meat for I.C.C. Bgde. Reached Jericho at 12.15 p.m. & found that orders had been altered and the meat had been given to feed the Syrian refugees in Jericho.

Returned to position at 3.45 p.m. and went for a dip in the brook. Wadi-el Aujah.

3 taubes came over while in Jericho but went to Tel-el-Dum to bomb.

Rumored that Nab
a
lus has fallen to our troops.
Entry.100:
Stand to at 4 a.m. Afterwards grooming & feeding for camels and breakfast for us.

Jacko over at 10.15 a.m. One of our anti-aircraft shells failed to explode in the air and exploded on reaching the ground. 200 yds from our dugout.

Grazing picquet from 11 a.m. till 1 p.m.

At 3 p.m. heavy artillery bombardment commences and continues for 2 hrs or so. 18 pdrs,60 pdrs & 4.7 in. howitzers all firing.

"Jacko" made a counter attack and advanced 1000 yds. Our artillery then knocked out one of his guns and drove him back into a ravine.

Casualties on our side slight. "Jacko" threw over a good many coal boxes.

At 8.30 p.m. order to sadde up with strip saddles. Turned in at 9 p.m.

Enemy expected to attack tomorrow at 4 a.m.
Entry.101:
April 1918

Stand to at 4 a.m. Saddle up in full gear. Bivvy and all down. Enemy artillery started at 4.15 a.m. and threw over agood deal of shrapnel. Our artillery then opened a little but not so much as last evening.

Loads taken off saddles at 5.30 a.m. Breakfast and then off-saddle.

"Jacko's" attack this morning was a 
failure
.

Enemy plane over observing at 10.15 a.m.

Posted letter to Father.

At 11.30 a.m. mail – new Australian – arrives. A large mail and all are pleased with it.

Mounted picquet at 6.30 p.m. and am on 3rd shift from 10.30 pm. till 12.30 
p.m
. a.m.

Light Horse patrol capture German Major and 23 other ranks with plans of our guns & their positions, etc.

Enemy attack Mandesi Ford and are cut up with our artillery. Enemy losses 367 killed & wounded 2 officers & 51 O R prisoners.
Entry.102:
Stand to at 4 a.m. At 4.30 a.m. went on picquet till 6.30 a.m.

At 4.30 a.m. "Jacko" threw over shells till late in the morning. Our position was exposed and the shelling being too hot for us we were compelled to evacuate our position to another wadi¼ mile distant, and dug in again in a pretty good position near a 4.7 inch Howitzer Battery which shakes us all up when it fires.

1st Battn get out up. Road is covered by Jacko's guns & sand carts cannot go out to bring in wounded.

Picquet from 4.30 pm. to 6.30 pm.

Enemy put some shrapnel over in new position here. No casualties on our unit so far today.

Continued at 7.15 pm. a letter to Joy.

A party of Bearers went out to the front line tonight and returned at dawn 12th. For a wonder I was not included in this party, as I was on picquet.
Entry.103:
Stand to at 4 am. Fed up at 6.15 am.

Breakfast. Nothing doing so I finished the letter I continued last night.

Off saddle at 11 a.m.

Things active on right flank. Left flank weak and part of 2nd A.L.H. Bgde go to strengthen it.

Enemy cut up with a raid by 1st Battn with bombs 
last
 yesterday.

Word of staying in this position for 10 days to a fortnight. Group cooking cut outtemporarily and Company cooking begins.

Enemy searching for our batteries most of the day.

Turned in at "Lights Out" at 9 p.m.
Entry.104:
Out at 5.45 a.m. Parade for grooming and feeding at 6 a.m.

Things quiet after 8 a.m. so wrote some letters.

Messages of praise for last stunt read out.

Official notifiication of the fall of Kerak some days ago, to the Sharif of Mecca's troops.

4.7 in. Batty troubling "Jacko".

After dusk went to Wadi-el Aujah – the brook nearby – for a wash.

Rumors 
of a move prevalent.
Entry.105:
Up at 5.45 a.m. Grooming parade and feeding at 6 am.

Breakfast at 8 am or thereabouts.

Washed a few clothes.

Issued with extra water bottle through Bgde.

Grazing parade at 9. a.m.

Watering at 1.30 p.m.

Things quiet except for "Jacko's" observation planes, 2 or 3 times each day.

Peace rumors at 8.30 pm tonight, from Jericho.

A month today since we left Dieran.
Entry.106:
Routine as usual in early morning.

"Jacko" planes over observing early at 7.30 a.m.

Despatch runner to Bgde Hd Qrs today. 1st trip 9 a.m.

Not much doing till evening when as usual through the usual bungling of the orderly room staff it was 10 pm by the time I was back at bivouac.

Wrote letter No. 41 this morning.
Entry.107:
Early morning routine as usual.

Grazing picquet from 9.15 a.m. till 10.45 a.m.

Returned to bivouac and wrote a letter.

While on grazing picquet the nose caps fromour anti craft shells came unbearably close so I retired to a cave in the rocks for a few minutes till the enemy machine had made his observations and returned to his own lines. Watering at 1.30 pm.

After 7.30 pm. went for a wash.
Entry.108:
Usual early morning routine.

Warned for picquet tonight

Things quiet so far today at 10.30 a.m.

Still no sign of any paper mail from the last 3 letter mails.

Mounted picquet at 6.30 a.m. I am 1st post for the next 24 hrs. On from 6.30 pm to 8.30 pm.

British Howitzers move through Jericho tonight & take up position in theValley of Jordan.
Entry.109:
Picquet from 12.30 
p
a.m. till 2.30 a.m. and from 6.30 to 8.30 a.m. 12.30 p.m. till 2.30 pm this afternoon.

Attack expected tonight by our troops.

Our artillery active this morning.

Light Horse move past our position in the direction of Mandesi Ford. 
Word
 Furphy of us moving.

Wrote a letter (42).

A few small items from Comforts Funds.

Friday 19April 1918

Up till 11 a.m. today no attack has been launched by either ourtroops or the enemy.

Our artillery & enemy also active.

Received parcel at 11.30 a.m. from Jack dated about Feb 14th 1918. (A surprise out here).

One 18 pdrs. Batty now over the Jordan& Howitzer near by.

Ammon stunt seems highly probable again, this time with more foundation in the previous one.

At 6.30 pm received parcel from Father, Packet of local papers from D'nong Patric League and 2 copies of "Punch" (Jan 17th &
Entry.110:
from Joy.

Voluntary church parade held. Attended it.
Entry.111:
Early morning routine as usual. Today am Fd. Amb. detail for chlorination of water tanks in Wadi-el-Auja.

Wrote a note home at 11 a.m. after the mornings job.

Down at the water troughs again at 12.30 pm & by 1.30 pm was finished for the afternoon till stables at 4.30 pm.

Some of the boys had a sing-song in the wadi, this evening.
Entry.112:
Stables at 5.45 a.m.

Breakfast and then duty as cook's asst.

(Writing paper given to me.) Much needed too.

Made up into 2 parcels the 2 books of "Views and flowers of the Holy Land". 1 to be sent to Joy and one to Olive.

A parcel of 3 V.P.Kfilms made up 
and
 to be sent to Colonial PhotoStores, 31 Ramleh St. Alexandria.

Letter to hand from Ted Holden.

No church parade.

Finished duty at 6.35 pm.
Entry.113:
Routine as usual this morning. Grazing picquet from 8 a.m. to 10.30 a.m.

"Jacko" paid us his usual visit (at 10.45 a.m. today)

Watered camels at 1.30 pm.

At 2.45 pm. a party of us under an N.C.O and a Medical Officer went to the Wadi-El-Auja to carry out certain work in connection with the prevention of the breeding of malarial mosquitos. Returned to bivouac at 5.45 pm.

Warned this evening in regard to the exposing of naked lights after 7 pm.

Night air raids expected now as the moon is nearing full.

Intend to dig a funk-hole tomorrow as a protection.

(Have not yet sent the parcels away) (Intend doing so tomorrow without fail)
Entry.114:
No raid last night. Dug a funk-hole this morning.

Early morning routine.

At 4 p.m. detailed to goto Jericho to the dump 1½ mls. the other side, with another chap and 7 led camels to get Reinfts. Arrived Jericho dump at 7.30 pm. and reached bivouac at 11.30 pm.

Turned in at midnight.
Entry.115:
Routine.

Detailed for picquet for 24 hrs. from 6.30 pm. this evening.

Wrote a note home.

Geo Cameron evacuated sick to Anzac Clearing Station, Jericho.

A N.S.W chap, one of the original boys is now with me. I will miss George as we have been together for the last 11 months (on active service.)

Started letter (43).

All our batteries started fiting at 8 pm. and continued for 20 mins when all was silent.

3rd relief on picquet tonight. 10.30 p.m. to 12.30 a.m.

Posted parcels tonight for Geo Cmon and myself.
Entry.116:
On picquet. 4.30 a.m. to 6.30 a.m. 10.30 a.m. to 12.30 pm. 4.30 pm to 6.30 pm.

Howitzer Batty changing over and operations apparent.

Posted letter (43).

A Christmas Box from the Australian Red Cross given to each member of this unit A.C.F.A.

Full moon tonight. Air raid expected.
Entry.117:
Artillery on our left flank busy all night, and this morning.

Camels mange dressed at M.V.S. today.

Wrote a few short letters.

What with the movement of troops and batteries of artillery & howitzers the Ammon stunt now seems a certainty in less than a week.

On a working party in the Wadi-Auja this morning.
Entry.118:
Artillery activity in the Nablus sector continues

On grazing picquet for 3 hrs. this morning.

Rumors of an Australian mail "somewhere". Hardly believed.

Letter from Charlie Thompson this afternoon. 
Austl
.
Entry.119:
No church parade today.

Light Horse Bgdes 
and H.K. Batty
 change over and H.K. Batty take a spell of a day or so.

Wrote a letter tonight.

The Hong Kong & Singapore Batty are attached to the Australian Mounted Division for the coming 2nd stunt on Ammon.
Entry.120:
On working party in Wadi Auja.

2nd attempt to take Ammon is apparently commencing tonight or early tomorrow morning.

From all appearances the Camel Brigade will not cross the Jordan on this stunt, but will hold with other troops the line on the sector where we are at present.

A section of Fd Amb. detailed to go 
to
 with 4th Battn when they attack near the 
War
 Ghoraniyeh Ford.

Wrote home. No. (28) to Mother.
Entry.121:
A little after 2 
p.m
 a.m. our artillery commenced firing and have continued so till now 9.30 a.m. and are still going strong.
Entry.122:
far the operations of this morning are successful.

Finished letter No(44).

On QM's asst.

At 5 pm. operations continue.

Light Horse are now in a direction round the back of Shunet Nimrin and well on the way to Es Salt.

Shunet Nimrin redoubt has fallen but enemy troops are strongly dug in just a little behind under the rocks.

Our troop's casualties are fairly heavy on the Shunt Nm sector.

4th Battn I.C.C. took their objective without opposition.

A large fire is burning in the enemy lines.

This afternoon the Light Horse advanced across the flat under enemy shell fire.
Entry.123:
From 2 am. our artillery pounded away round Shunet Nimrin, and all along the flat to the left is now at 7 a.m. being shelled both by our guns and the enemy.

Grazing guard 8 a.m. till 9.30 am.

1112.30 pm.

Es Salt has now fallen.

New Zealand Mtd. Division Hospital is to move tonight across Jordan River and on the way to Es Salt.

2nd Battn were ambushed and suffered severe casualties from enemy machine gun fire.

At 3 pm. "Jacko" retook a hill. A Howitzer Batty that was putting up a barage ran out of ammunition thus giving Jacko a chance.

(C.O. back from leave.)

A pair of slacks?

Planes go over Jacko's lines on a bombing raid
Entry.124:
Enemy artillery fire is concentrated on our troops East of Shunet Nimrin while our fire is in a slighly modified formon his troops further East at 8 am.

Warned for picquet tonight.

Summer clothing issued and I got a pair of new Australian boots –a God send.

At 2.30 pm. bivvies down and saddle up in full gear. Moved to the other side of the Wadi-el-Auja about 1½ miles from our original position and nearer the line.

Bivouaced among the stunted prickly bushes and undergrowth a short distance from Bgde Hd. Qrs. Bivouac area spread out on the flat here and everything camouflaged to guard against ovservation from hostile aircraft.

Several of our planes go over on bombing raid about dusk. Mounted picquet at 7 pm.

Jacko sent his planes over bombing our attacking troops over theJordan River.

Could not sleep tonight for enemy artillery fire.
Entry.125:
Enemy continue activity with artillery fire until dawn.

On picquet 1st post.

At 10 a.m. our howitzers near by open up and at 10.30 are still going strong.

Rumored that "Jacko" captured 9 guns of ours on the flat the other day.

Several of our unit including an M.O have been evacuated with malaria.

Don't go too much on our "possy" here somehow.

Enemy plane came over and made an observation of our position at 2 pm.

At daybreak 3 
of our
 enemy planes bombed 
"Jacko's"
 our lines & again at 5 pm.

Artillery activity slowed down in afternoon & continued for a while at 5 pm.

Wrote letter (30) to home.

(Relieved from picquet at 6.30 pm.)

At 9 p.m. the Advd Dressg Stn party from 4th Battn came back.
Entry.126:
Aircraft busy again at daybreak but not on our position.

(Things in the lines more like normal as the Advanced Dressing Station party from 4th Battn have rejoined us) (Special 
reference
 circumstances in regard to putting this in diary)

At 7.30 am. artillery, rifle & machine gun fire at a medium.

At 5 pm. our howitzers near by opened up for an hr. or so and ceased at dark with the exception of an occasional shot.

Wrote and posted No (45).

My goodold "Swan Safety" has gone crook on me tonight while writing.

Received parcel from Ted Holden.

I am on cooks asst. today.
Entry.127:
Jacko over at dawn and at 5.20 a.m. he came down and put his machine gun around our position.

No casualties. He seems to have found out where HdQrsis so what with searching for our howitzers and HdQrshe may give our "possy" a lively time.

Given out in orders that 850 prisoners have been taken lately – including a number of Germans.

Whether our troops have given up Es Salt again is doubtful. A good many things point to it, all the same.

Got canteen stores. Wrote a couple of notes.

Howitzer Batteries busy today especially at 10 a.m.

At 8 a.m. Light Horse are moving back from Es Salt to this side of Jordan River.

Received parcel of photos registered from Colonial Photo Stores, Alexandria.

Our troops are moving in thousands along the road near our position up to the line tonight.

Monday 6 May 1918

Thingsas usual during early morning.

At 8 am. Jacko planed down and put his machinegun around a bit but no result.

In the matter of troops around here things have increased considerably.

Our troops have evacuated Es Salt and had to destroy a lot of their own stores and transport wagons in the 
ret
reat
 withdrawl.

Shunet Nimrin has also been evacuated so the line is now practically the same as it was after the 1st Ammon stunt therefore the 2nd Ammon stunt is a larger failure that the 1st one.

The place is alive with artillery here and troops also. Next move seems a querry.

On grazing guard till 12.45 p.m.

Received 4 letters from Australia (No 29 Joy.)

Expect to have a hot time in the position we are now in.

This afternoon our artillery shook us up firing directly behind us and close by. 

14 of the
Entry.128: L.H.Fd.Amb. have been captured including Jim Briant.
Entry.129:
At dawn 9 enemy bombing planes came over and dropped bombs at the back of our position.

Finished letter (46) at 10.30 a.m., just when the batteries behind usopened on "Jacko".

At 8.30 am. 2 more bombing planes came over but dropped nothing on our position.

Lucky again for us but Light Horse suffered.
Entry.130:
May 1918

(9 pm just before lights out)

Still going strong.

Received a parcel from home and one from Joy.



At 5 a.m. 8 enemy planes came over before we were awake. Bombs were dropped around our position but no casualties occurred in our unit.

Have been ordered to dig in on this account mainly. Larger raid expected tomorrow morning and precautions are being taken.

At 5pm. Hong Kong Batty on our left and slightly ford opened on Jacko's position until dark.

Parcel mail arrived. Received parcel from Home and parcel containing birthday cake from Joy. Acknowledged by F.C. Cards.

Rumors of our position being taken over by and Camel Brigade going back a little.
Entry.131:
No raid from "Jacko" planes this morning. A relief too.

At 8.30 am. our artillery open up.

Applications for transfer (or exchange) to Govt Hospital Suez are called.

I am giving it a "fly" for a spell from the field. Found out at 12.30 that I was not successful in my application.

Received letter from Geo. Cameron tonight.

Paidtonight –drew 500 PT's.

On picquet tonight for following 24 hrs. Struck 3rd relief.

In the Battalions the chaps are being sent to hospital in large numbers – breaking up with the weather conditions.

The Battery chaps who lost their 8 or 9 guns on the last Ammon stunt go up into the line tonight to dig trenches.

These chaps fired their ammunition to the last round, when the Light Horse was short of same and fodder also.
Entry.132:
No enemy raiding planes over this morning. Observation only.

Replied to Geo. Cam's letter today.

It is 12 months today since we embarked from Victoria.

Had a sing-song this evening as a sort of reunion among the old boys – 43 of which are now with us out of 97 that left with origl unit.

Word of moving tomorrow night. Lt Horse taking over.

Our artillery shelling Jordan Flats.
Entry.133:
No raid from enemy planes today but at frequent intervals Jacko came over in ones and twos but dropped no bombs.

On grazing guard (2nd post)

At 3.30 pm. all bivvies were down and all camels saddledup in full gear ready to move off.

Moved off shortly after (and left with their gear those who have no camels) and travelled till about dusk¼ mile from the Waddy at the foot of steep mountains a few miles from Jericho.

The Light Horse (Aust. Mtd. Divisn) are now going into the line. With the dust they are in a pitiful condition and fully show what they have to put up with.

Troops are everywhere on the flat and in the waddies. Sand carts left the line under cover of night and the Battalions also came up.
and are now close by at

Our destination is a ? to us all.

Several boys knocked up with the heat today.
Entry.134:
Turned out at 5 am. 3 planes are already over on observation.

(The guns on the line are only a rumble to us now.)

Moved at dusk and travelled 
this
 till midnight on the old Roman road from Jericho to Jerusalem.

Air getting colder as we leave the Jordan flats and by midnight is cold.

A complete change to where we have been the last month.

Enemy plane observed our movements at dusk.
Entry.135:
At 2 a.m. we halted at Talatedum near the Inn of the Good Samaritan. Turned in after off saddling the camels and out again at 5.30 am.

My 21st birthday and at Talatedum½ way between Jerich and Jerusalem.

Watered camels this morning at the old Roman wall
½ way betwe
 dividing the territory of Jericho from that of Jerusalem. This wall is a pass in the Mtand tolls were gathered here. Remains of the wall are still there, crumbling away.

The motor wagons carry all supplies etc from Jeruslm to Jericho now. C.T.C. for this stage being done away with.

Saddle up at 6.30 pm. and at 9.15 pm. or thereabouts the Ambulance moved off behind the Brigade. A beautiful road the whole way.

Reached Bethany 
and Garden of Gethsemene at
 at midnight, 
Garden of Gethsemene, Church of St Stephen, Mount of Olives at 1.30 pm (and as we passed through the main part of the Holy City the clock towers shimed 2 pm.)
Entry.136:
The
 A clock in one of the towers of the Holy City chimed 2 am. as we passed through Jerusalem.

Saw plainer tonight what this City is like. Passed by the Jaffa Gate in the wall ofthe Old City. From here we took a main road to Nth. West of Bethlehem.

At 6 am. we halted near the village of Kuryet El Enab and offsaddled – something to eat and turned in to get some rest to make up for the 2 nights previous. All feeling done out.

The mountainous nature of the country was such that in many places we had to walk and lead the camels.

Saddle up at 6 pm. and moved at dusk

Arrived at Latroun at 11.30 pm.

(Garden of Gethsemene, Mtof Olives & Church of St Stephen were passed by at 1.30 am)

"Armies" of E.L.C. are engaged repairing the roads.
Entry.137:
In bivouac at Latroun (Le-Toun). Turned out at 6.15 am.

Orderly Room duties today

Orders for moving to Dieran at 4 am tomorrow. Turned in early.

5 Reinfts have joined us today;one of them an old ACFA chap.

Latroun is situated on the road to Ramleh 19 miles from Jerusalem. On a mount near 
our and
 Mtd BivouacArea is a castle built by the Knights of St John in the year 1100 
B.C.
A.D.

It is now crumbling to ruins and is used as ashelter for Bedouins. There is some fine work in stone inside the walls.

Latroun is now a large intermediate dump and intermediate base, also a large motortransport depot.
Entry.139:
Turned out at 3.30 a.m. and saddled up in full marching order. Left Latroun at 4.30 a.m. or thereabouts and travelled till 8.45 a.m.

Breakfasted at 9 
p
 a.m. and on again reaching Dieran at 12 noon and bivouaced in a waddy 2 miles from Dieran at 1.15 pm.

Bivouac area set out as though we may be here some time at least.

Heard that Camel Bgde dump at Rafa is to be moved to Dieran and we are to be quartered in bell tents while 
resting
 here "
we believe"
.

Drew water at Gen. Hd Qrs watering place in Dieran in afternoon and went to Canteen.

The country here is really great in appearance with the hedges, fruit trees and vineyards in leaf. The grass here is by no means dry and forms a striking contrast to the country in the Jordan Valley. New Aust. mail expected tomorrow.

Friday 17
Entry.140:
Reveille at 6.30 a.m. Stables at 6.45 am.

Turned out camels to graze after breakfast.

Camels inspected by Brig. Gen of Bgde during afternoon.

Started letter but unable to finish it.

Mounted picquet at 6.30 pm. 1st post viz:– 6.30 pm tll 8.30 pm. 12.30 
p
a.m till 2.30 a.m.



Saturday 18 May 1918

Reveille 5.30 am. Stables 5.45 am.

On picquet at 6.30 am again till 8.30 am.

Saddled up camels and with midday meal in our haversacks went to the beach for the day. Had a good time surfing. Returned to bivouac at 4 p.m.

My bivvy mate has been evacuated to Hospl with a crook arm so I am now once again "on my lonesome".

Repitched bivvy after tea and started to write the letters I have already begun. Completed letter No (47).
Entry.141:
Reveille 5.30 a.m. Stables 5.45 am.

On grazing guard from 6.30 am till 8.30 a.m.

Missed watering parade on this account and went to canteen in afternoon.

Wrote home to Mother.
Entry.142:
Reveille and stable routine as usual.

Published in orders regarding leave to Port Said for 1 Officer & 10 O.R. I put in for it.

At 8 am. 
took
 Amb. took blankets & kit etc to fumigating train to be fumigated. Returned to bivouac at 12.15 pm.

At Kilo 295 I met several chaps who were at the dumps at Jerusalem & Rafa while we were in the field. "Lucky beggars on "
cushy
" jobs".

During evening took camels to M.V.S.
Entry.143:
Routine as usual.

Notified that I am to go on leave to Port Said tonight. Leaving here at 8.30 pm.

Saddle up at 7.30 pm. Reported Hd Qrs at 8.30 and trotted to the station at Kilo 295. Dieran. Entrained at 10.30 and travelled all night in an open truck with coal dust and tibbin in it and we got plenty of cinders from the engine. Train jolted and bumped all night –it was some ride –.
Entry.144:
At 11.30 a.m. we arrived at Kantara West and disentrained. Kits put on motor wagons and we marched to Kantara East.

Had breakfast at Mrs. Chisholms and caught train to Port Said at 3 p.m. Arrived Port Said at 4 pm. and headed by a band marched to Rest Camp.

Given our tents and pass for 10 days and we were set.
Entry.145:
Had a look round during morng and then was paid at 11.30 pm. Drew£11.

Got new suit of uniform in the City.
Entry.146: Did not go for a dip or a shower – too tired–. Wrote a letter to Joy and to Arthur Thompson. Into the city to do some purchasing and have a look round. Morning tea. Dinner. Afternoon tea. Went to 14th A.G.H. over canal. Saw Geo. Cameron and a number of the old boys there. Ted Holden wants me to get on the staff. Am undecided on this point.Tea at the "Continental" at 7.30 p.m. at a table we had reserved. Had some fun here as it was Empire Day and everyone "patriotic" as they were "full'.
Entry.147:
Shower at 6.30 a.m. Breakfast 7.30 a.m.

Wrote a note home.

Went into the city again to do some shopping.

Met a lot of chaps I knew both in camp in Victoria, Moascar, Abbassia; & in Palestine in the field.

Posted parcel to Olive & one to Joy.

Sunday 26May 1918

Had a general look round the place of Port Said and enjoyed the day generally.
Entry.148:
On leave.

Went to city in morning and then went for a drive round for an hr. Had dinner at Y.M.C.A. Hostel near Canal Company's gardens.

Had a clean up in the city and then to the 14th A.G.H. the other side of the canal during afternoon.

Ted Holden who wants 
me
 to get me on the staff of the
Entry.149:
A.G.H. introduced me to the W.O. (Rowe) and is trying to arrange an exchange for me.

Met Les Leversha & Frank Bayley in evening and we had tea together.

During morning purchased 2 articles (silk) One to send to Olive & one to Joy. Had them sent to Australia by the firm "Au Mikado" at which I purchased them.
Entry.150:
On leave.

In the city during morning and in afternoon along the beach.

At 6 pm watched the fishing trawlers unload their days haul; and the numerous submarine chasers and cargo boats entering Port Said.

Went to Hotel De La Poste for the evening and tea.

Back to Rest Camp in a gharry at 9pm.

Just after dinner wrote a letter to Joy.

Got photos of stunt from Frank Bayley.
Entry.151:
On leave.

In city during morning. Had morning tea and lunch and came back to Rest Camp at 12.30 p.m.

Went at 3.30 pm to meet Jim Tatterson from 14th A.G.H.

Saw Jim in the city & he has everything fixed this end, so I am right if my own C.O. agrees to the exchange.

Spent evening in city.
Entry.152:
At 10 am. went to the Armenian Refugee Camp on the bank of the Suez Canal about 1 hrs. sail in a yacht. Had a look over all their camp and after buying a few articles to sent to Australia, got into the yacht and returned to Port Said at 1.15 pm. to have lunch at "Trianon".

On the way back, watched a sea plane land and come up the canal on the water to the aerodrome.

Saw a sunken ammunition boat. Divers bringing up shells, – at least fastening shells to ropes which were then drawn ro the surface.

Went to 14th A.G.H. in afternoon & left at 5.15 pm.

Had tea at the "Continental" & back to Rest Camp at 9.15 pm.

At the Armenian Camp I sent a souvenir to Mother, 
and
 one to Joy and one to Vida.
Entry.153:
Given out on parade this morning that we are to hold ourselves in readiness to move out today, and at 10 a.m. all passes to be handed in to Orderly Room.

Took a run into city and had morning tea, at the same time saying "goodbye" to our waiter friend at the "Trianon Cafe"

At 12 noon it is announced that we will not go today & passes are returned to us. Went to Y.M.C.A. Rest House and wrote up diary and photos.
Entry.154:
Left camp headed by band and marched to Port Said station where we entrained and left at 12.30 pm.

Arrived at Kantara West at 1.30 pm.

Marched to Kantara East and then were free till 4.30 pm.

Went to Y.M.C.A. for something to eat and left Kantara East in trucks (better ones this time) at 6.15 pm.

Travelled till midnight but got next to no sleep.
Entry.155:
Still travelling at midnight and at 12 midday arrived at Dieran Kilo 295.

Led camels & were there and we went straight to the camp. Got my mail 19 letters altogether, Letters dates as late as Apr11th in them.

Started to answer them tonight.

Received parcel of 2 prs of socks from home.

(Jones of 3 not too good.)
Entry.156:
Writing letters most of the day and evening till "lights out" at 9.30 pm.

Posted one to Joy.
Entry.157:
Usual routine this morning at 5 a.m. 12 of our planes went over on a bombing expedition & later "Jacko" came over observing at 6 a.m.

Posted one to Mother, & Harry Coleman (in France)

Wrote a couple of short letters today.

No word yet about the exchange.
Entry.158:
Early morning routine. 
Wrote a couple of short letters today
.

Word of moving to another camping ground on acct of the knowledge of those in command in selecting this mosquito infested site on 16th May.

Rumored of the disbanding of the Camel Corps.
Entry.159:
Early morning routine.

Moved off at 12.30 p.m. from this camp site at Dieran to a new camp site near the village of Surofind on the main Jaffa 
Road
 - Ramleh road. We are now 2½ miles above railhead.

Busy pitching tents etc. till dark when tea was ready.

Turned in at "lights out" 9.30 pm.

The big guns are distinctly heard & the flashes of their firing is plainly seen.

Our planes active until late this evening –being practically dark when they returned to aerodrome.
Entry.160:
Busy putting up "bell" and "E.P." tents this morning and fixing up camp site generally.

There 
are
 were any amount of our planes up at dawn.

Things as usual in the camp

Natives are selling tomatoes, (a few oranges) cucumbers, and apricots which are tasty.

The application of the chap who wants to exchange with me, is now in our orderly room. My applicatn is attached and will tomorrow morning go before the C.O. of this Amb.
Entry.161:
June 1918

Reveille 5.30 am. but we were awake at 3.45 am. when the monitors 
and b
 on sea and heavy artillery 
on
 
land
 opened up with one roar. At 10 am they are still going strong.

Wrote letter to Olive this morning.

At 10 am. made enquiries and foundthat the C.Ohas seenmy application and so far has done nothing further in the matter.

At 4 pm. the bombardment is still going strong and we hear that our troops have gained all their objectives on that sector.

Jewish conference at Surafend; to discuss the formation of a Jewish army in Palestine for service in the field.

Wrote to Joy tonight.

A wind-up concert of I.C.CBgde is being held in the Y.M.C.A. marquee tonight
Entry.162:
Usual early morning routine

On enquiry at 
10 pm
 9 a.m. was informed that my application was attached with Wellmans and approved by our C.O. It was thenforwarded to the D.D.M.Sfor his approval.
Entry.163:
Usual routine this morning.

Received 4 letters from a new Australian mail.

Am informed that I am to go on leave to Jaffa tomorrow for 12 hrs. from 9 am.

Messages of congratulation for I.C.C. Bgde read out to us from 
G.
O.C. commanding.
Entry.164:
Left at 9 a.m. for Jaffa. Arrived there at 11 a.m. or thereabouts.

Spent the day there. May a few purchases.

Returned to camp at 7 pm. on my "
Special Visitors Pass
".

Received 4 more letters from Australia. This is good oh!

2 of our boys were pinched by Tommy M.P.'s

Received photos 
from
 of "
Home
" from Jack.
Entry.165:
Early morning routine.

Informed that my transfer has been approved by D.D.M.S. so expect to go down in a day or so to Port Said.

Wrote and posted letter to Father & Joy. Reg Envelope of 21 snaps to Joy also.
Entry.166:
Early morning routine.

Notified that I am to go to Port Said tomorrow night.

Jacko is shelling a couple of villages on the flat and rise some miles over the road from us at 5 p.m.
Entry.167:
2nd Port Said leave party return to camp

Had to walk from Dieran to Ludd. Mismanagement again.

Packed up gear etc to leave at 2.30 p.m. Left with all kit and movement orders at 2.45 pm. after saying "goodbye" to the A.C.Fd A. chaps especially the old boys.

Rode to Ludd and caught the 4.15 pm train.

Travelled all night.

In a fairly decent truck and had a little sleep.
Entry.168:
Arrived at Kantara at 6.30 a.m. Disentrained and placed gear and ourselves in a 
dirty motor wagon
 ("malish") Driven to Kantara East. Caught 11 am. train to Port Said.

Disentrained at Pt Said at 12.15 pm. Arrived at 14th A.G.H at 1 pm.

Had a swim and then fresh water shower.

(Think I will be alright if I don't strike the ward work.)
Entry.169:
Reveille 6 a.m. Fall in 6.30 a.m. Roll call & orders read. One or two elementary inf. drill movements;then march off to respective duties etc.

Was put on Ward No 7 for an hr. or so, then taken to Isolation on an easy job. It will do me if they leave me on it while I am here.

I will have a properbed tonight. Spring mattress, tick, sheets, pillow & pillow slip and all blankets reqd. First time on such a bed since I left Australia.

Wrote to Joy this afternoon.
Entry.170:
On the job. Took the place of one of the chaps who is off color so had considerably more to do in afternoon.

Feeling tired tonight.

Wrote to Eric Redwood.
Entry.171:
Fairly stiff morning till 11.30 a.m.

Had a swim. Dinner & an easy afternoon.

Wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.172:
Fairly stiff morning but afternoon off.

Pay and then went to Port Said for afternoon and evening.
Entry.173:
On the go again this morning butan easy afternoon.

Wrote to Mother tonight.
Entry.174:
Usual general duties on Isolation.

Unloaded or rather helped to unload convoy of wounded in afternoon.

7 of the A.C.F.A boys are in the Pt. Said Rest Camp for 10 days, & this afternoon paid a visit to the 14th A.G.H.
Entry.175:
Usual work in morning and during afternoon had a look at the "Aquatic 
Exhibition
 Carnival" at the 14th A.G.H.

Met Harry Thompson at the Y.M.C.A. He is coming over to see me next week.

Received 4 readdressed letters from last mail.

Was my afternoon off but have somehow slipped for it.
Entry.176:
Easy morning and afternoon off

Went in for usual swim at 12 noon.

On leave from 2 p.m till 10 pm. to Pt. Said. Left 14th A.G.H at 4.15 pm & took a yacht to the other side of the canal.

Went for a walk along the beach & then had tea. Went to Cinema at 6 pm. & when this finished at 8.15 pm. went to a dance hall. Had one or two dances with Alf Vivash that I was on leave with.
Entry.177:
Fairly stiff morning & fair afternoon.

No swim today.

Tuesday 25June 1918

Usual morning and easy afternoon till 4 p.m.

Went in swimming at 5.30 pm.

(The trouble that the Sister in Charge of Isolation 
takes
 
took
 takes with us and our tea 
this
 every afternoon speaks volumes for her as a "
lady
".)

Received letter from Eric Redwood.

Met Norman McKinnon &"Titch" Cohen, who are patients in hospital.

In the convoy of 141 patients that arrived here today on the "Niagra" Hospital Boat was Chas Lockie from
Entry.178:
L.H.F.A. and Hutchinson from our Ambulance at Ludd.

Vivash went to Alex. & Cairo on leave.

Wrote a few short letters, including one to Arthur & one to Charlie Thompson.
Entry.179:
Did a full mornings work and went to Port Said at 4 p.m. Met Harry Thompson at Y.M.C.ARest House & Tea Rooms.

Returned to camp at 6.30 p.m. and went in swimming till 7.30.

Wrote a couple of letters & turned in after a stroll along the breakwater for¾ mile.
Entry.180:
Usual morning's work.

Swim for½ hr. before dinner.

Duty as "runner" for afternoon.

Swimming at 5.30 till 7.15 pm.

A hospital boat for Australia is very probably going next week.

I will likely be on night duty for next month, and it should do me.

(Percy Knight is in Hospital.)
Entry.181:
Fairlystiff day.

One of the boys in our tent is going to Aust. on the boat in a few days time & tonight he had to "wet" the occasion.
Entry.182:
Easy mornings work and leave in afternoon.

Went to Port Said at 3.45 pm. and out to D.M.C. Rest Camp where I had arranged to meet Harry Thompson. Had a yarn with him for 1½ hrs – showed him Mac's latest letter & some of my snaps.

Returned to Hospital at 7 pm. although I had a pass till 10 pm.

This morning the boarded patients who are going to Aust. on the next boat were issued with all their shortages in kit. It is surprising what kit 
they
 were able to get.
Entry.183:
Nothing much from ordinary routine.

Warned for night shift next month & relieved from day duties at 12 noon.

Am to start tonight on the huts.

Went on duty at 7 p.m. and carried on till 12 midnight.
Entry.184:
1918

Finished duty at 7 a.m. Went for swim and turned straight into bed.

Turned out at 2.30 p.m. Had a shower & afternoon tea & sat down to write a letter.

Went on duty at 7 p.m. till 12 midnight.
Entry.185:
1918

Duty from 12 midnight till 7 a.m.

Had a swim and turned in to bed.

Slept well till 3.45 pm. Turned out. Had a shower and after cleaning up had tea.

Went on duty at 7 p.m.

Made tea for the 2 Sisters
 and when things were settled at 9 pm. the other night duty chap & I prepared supper for 12.30.

Supper consisted of fried chops, boiled and chip potatoes and tea. It went well.

There were the night sister & the night superintendent (sister) night Sgt, Vivash, Ives & Self. Quite a party.

Wrote up diary from 3 to 4 a.m
.
Entry.186:
1918

Wrote up diary and a letter between 3 & 4 a.m.

Had a swim just after 7 a.m.

Turned in to bed.

Up at 1.30 pm. Got cleaned & went to Port Said to meet Harry Thompson at Y.M.C.A. at Rest Camp

Pay at 6.30 p.m.

On duty 7 pm. till 12 midnight

Large batches of leave parties from the field are now arriving at DM.C. Rest Camp Port Said.

Another lot of 
our
 boys A.C.Fd.Amb. are down.

Wrote to Joy at 3 a.m.
Entry.187:
1918

On from midnight till 7 a.m.

Had a swim for 1 hr. & then turned in

Up at 4 pm. Tea etc & on duty at 7 pm.
Entry.188:
1918

On duty from midnight till 7 a.m.

As usual the rest of the day.

Duty again at 7 pm till midnight.
Entry.189:
1918

Duty midnight till 7 a.m.

Posted "Kia-Ora Cooee" to Jack.

Rest of day as usual.

Went to Port Said at 4 p.m. & to Rest Camp. Saw Harry Thompson.
Entry.190:
1918

(
On from 7 to midnight.
)

On from 12 midnight to 7 a.m.

Rest of the day as usual.

Met a Cpl who was in Med Details to 12 Regt C. Squadron 4 Bgde & who knew 592 George Kelley who was killed at 
Beersheba
 Beit el Foka .

Poste booklet of "Historical Sites in Southern Palestine" to Father.
Entry.191:
July1918

As usual when on night shift

Had a yarn with a Sgt. Cooper about how & where Geo. Kelley met his death.

Feeling tired tonight.
Entry.192:
1918

As usual.

Feeling tired & done out this morning

On duty at 7 p.m.

At an invitation went to a picnic with 4 sisters & a number of patients & staff.

Had a great time.

Received Australian mail this afternoon 14 letters. Had only time to read one before the picnic. Was asleep at 1 pm. when Sister Scott had me awakened & asked to go on a Red Cross picnic this afternoon. Went down the Canal a few miles in the motor launch "Dina Dynasty V". Picnicked & returned to hospital at¼ to 7 pm. Had a great afternoon. The patients & Sisters being real "sports".
Entry.193:
1918

As usual.

Received a letter from Arthur Thompson.

Work busier & heavier now on Huts of a night-time in Isolation.

Wrote a letter to Joy & Home to be given to Pte Davies who is going to Australia on transport duty & joins the transport "Port Darwin" tomorrow. (Thursday)
Entry.194:
1918

On till 7 a.m.

Said good-bye to Davies this morning.

As I write this the walking cases for Australia are being cheered as the boat moves off. (7.30 
p
a.m.) to join the "Port Darwin."

On duty at 7 p.m.

Wrote letter to Olive.
Entry.195:
1918

Off duty at 7 a.m.

Went for swim. Breakfast at 8 a.m.

Bed at 9 a.m. or thereabouts.

Up at 4.30 p.m.

Shower and cleaned up.

Swim at 6 p.m. On duty at 7 p.m.

My knee is affecting me a bit lately.
Entry.196:
1918

As usual.

Received parcel from "Home". It contained Sugar, Cocoa & Milk, BiscuitsSoap, tobacco & cigars, & insectibane.
Entry.197:
1918

As usual this morning.

Went to Pt Said in afternoon.

On duty at 7 p.m.
Entry.198:
July1918

On duty till 7 a.m. and on again at 7 pm.

Crook toe, can hardly walk.
Entry.199:
1918

As usual to 7 a.m.

Rest of day also.

Reports that "Jacko" has attacked on the JdnValley Sector but failed with heavy losses.
Entry.200:
1918

Things as usual.

Wrote to Father & posted Kia-Ora Cooee to Olive.

All drivers are to be recalled to the Field so it seems. Don't expect this will affect me.
Entry.201:
July1918

As usual.

Wrote 2 letters tonight.
Entry.202:
1918

Went to Port Said during afternoon.

Saw Harry Thompson for 1½ hrs.
Entry.203:
1918

As usual.

Met (Sgt.) Gammow today as a patient in Hospital.
Entry.204:
1918

As usual.

"Special" case of Tetanus in Isolation now on my duties so there's a deal more work doing.

Foot seen by Cpt Jaske & advised to look afterit as his treatment ordered.

Received 4 letters from Australia (3 from Home & one from D'nong.)

Heard news by cable of latest operations in France.
Entry.205:
1918

Boat expected to sail for Australia shortly.

3 of the 14th A.G.H. staff are going on transport duty. Jim Tatterson is one.

Received 2 letters from France– one from Harry Coleman & the other from Charlie Thompson–.
Entry.206:
July1918

Things as usual.

Met Percy Knight from 7th Sanitary Section. Has "shell shock"
Entry.208:
July1918

Nothing uneventful.

Received one local letter.
Entry.209:
1918

Crook tonight.

Sister in charge of special cases gave me a good spin so I had a rest for an hr. or so.

Received 3 letters – one from Tasmania & 2 local.

Camel Bgde have now got horses and are busy training. They are still at Ludd where I left them.
Entry.210:
1918

Things busy as usual from 3.30 to 7 a.m.

Rest of the day the same.
Entry.211:
July1918

As usual in duty line.

Received a couple of letters (Local ones) & 2 papers from Joy posted from Loch.
Entry.212:
1918

Received photos from Alexandria (Colonial Photo Stores.
Entry.214:
1918

Finished night duty for July at 7 a.m. Had a swim and turned in. Got up at 12 noon!

Had dinner. Met Eric Redwood down from Palestine to Rest Camp Port Said. He was visiting 14th A.G.H. Had a swim, & tea later ar 5 pm. Went to be paid at 6 pm.

Toe worse than usual today. Sister S-who is taking every interest in it wants me to parade sick with it.
Entry.215:
On day duty.

Saw Capt Jaske about my toe. His treatment is 
the
 to foment continually.

Otherwise had a good day.
Entry.216:
Easy morning's work till 12 noon.

Dinner &then half day off writing letters.
Entry.217:
Swimming Carnival held at 14th A.G.H. this afternoon.

Easy day today & had a good time.
Entry.220:
In bed with a septic knee which is affecting my leg as far as the hip

The same knee that I hurt at Amman among the rocks in Mts of Moab.
Entry.221:
August 1918

In bed & looked after very well by one of nursing staff Sisters who was more than considerate.

Received 5 letters by an Aust. mail

My pal was sent to Hosp with T 104º,
Entry.222:
In bed. Well treated.

Wrote a few letters sitting up in bed.
Entry.223:
Did a little today in the way of work.

Band Concert at wharf at Hospital.
Entry.224: Still going on easy with work of which I am not given much yet to do.
Entry.225:
Easy morning & off duty this afternoon.

On acctof knee could not go out on leave.

"Very Good" news in cables from Western Front.
Entry.226:
Got a letter from Harry Coleman in France.

Work as usual.

Knee still stiff & sore.

2
 Observer killed & pilot seriously injured in a plane accident at Aerodrome. R.F.C.
Entry.227: Things as usual. Met Thomas O. transferred from 31stGen. Hosp. Abbassia to
Entry.228:
A.G.H. for a board for classification. He ha
d
s a "cushy" crook hand.

Good news in latest cables from Western Front.

A.F.C. & R.F.C. planes bomb Amman Rly Station – camps in neighborhood & aerodrome. Score direct hits on Station & camps. Bombs burst agnst aeroplane hangars.

Wednesday 14August 1918

Just about to go on leave to Pt Said when along comes Arthur Thompson. Had a yarn & went to the city where we spent the 
off
 afternoon & evening.

Returned to Hosp. at 9.30 pm.
Entry.229:
Nothing 
un
eventful.

Received 3 local letters; & 2 packets of papers from Australia.

Met Eric Redwood who has extended leave from Palestine on account of being with the "Whizz-Bang" Concert Party at theD.M.C. Rest Camp – Pt Said

Heard that Geo Cameron has had a day or two in Cairo with kits from Amb. – 5th A.L.H.Fd.Amb.

Another plane accident at the Aerodrome close by Hospital.
Entry.230: Arthur Thompson came along in afternoon & had afternoon tea. He left at 4.30 p.m.
Entry.232:
Met Arthur Thompson in Pt. Said at 3 p.m. and spent the afternoon. Returned to Hosp. at 7.30 p.m.

Sunday 18 August 1918

Fairly busy at times but not "
too
 busy".

Wrote to Joy & Olive tonight.
Entry.233:
Wrote a couple of letters.

Rumored that an Eng. & Aust. mail is in Egypt.
Entry.235: Nothing eventful; but rough dusty & windy weather that shows signs of continuing.
Entry.236:
Easy morning & afternoon off.

Arthur Thompson & I went on board the H.M.A.S. "Warrego" (70) lying in the canal here.

Were treated well by the sailors & saw all over the destroyer & her weapons of warfare.

She came to Port Said last 
Thursday
 Fri 16th inst, from Brundisi in Italy where the Aust. destroyers have been on patrol for 12 months. Were glad to get where the Wallaby soldiers were once again. They leave tomorrow morning at 6 a.m. or tonight at midnight for Malta that will be their base now. They have a good deal of petrol aboard for Malta. Lying beside the 70 was a British navy "
mystery ship
" which is cleverly got up as a trap for enemy sub. craft & destroyers.

Cpl. F. went to Alex on leave
Entry.237:
Rather a busy morning and in afternoon went to Pt. Said with Ernie M-. Returned to Hosp at 6 p.m.

The 70 is gone from her moorings.

Wrote to Mother tonight & Joy yesterday.

Thomas O. will be on the staff of 14th tomorrow morning after 9 a.m.
Entry.238:
Busy morning & very busy afternoon – nearly enough to make one fed up with the job.

In evening "The Blue Dragoons" a Tommy Concert Party gave an entertainment in the Concert Hall at the 14th A.G.H. They were very good & "took well" with everyone.

Concert over at 10 p.m came back to quarters & turned in.
Entry.239:
Rather easy morning.

Wrote (67) to Joy.

Monday 26August 1918

Packed parcel of souvenirs that Lt Hearne 3rd L.H. Regt
Entry.240:
L.H. Bgde is taking to post in Australia for me.

Gave him 2 letters also to post for me.

Charlie Berry is going to Australia on the "Wiltshire" also.
Entry.241: Eric Redwood is in Hosp. – No 5 Ward – with Spanish Influenza. Has been in 4 days now. Returned his diary that he is having taken to Australia by a chap going on the "Wiltshire".
Entry.242:
"Wiltshire" men go tomorrow morning, from 14th A.G.H. 218 OR. & 19 Officers.

Wrote a couple of letters & posted them.

Transport "Ormonde" with 3000 Jewish Fusiliers (40th Royal) en route to Palestine is in the canal. This transport has just come from Plymouth. The "Ormonde" is the largest boat I have seen in the canal.
Entry.243:
Lighter with patients left Hosp. at 8 a.m.

X Aitchison & Berry from 
O
our Amb. are going home Aitchison on transport duty & Berry P.U. – permanently unfit.

Wrote to Joy.

Saw an up to date British "mystery ship" this afternoon.

X One of the few men in the army that treated me as 
dirt
 absolutely on the Beersheba - Gaza to Jaffa stint.
Entry.245:
Busy day but managed to work time for a swim in, at 6 p.m.

Am on the Q.M. job again forSept.

Met Arthur Thompson again this afternoon. On acct. of Spanish fever in the D.M.C. Rest Camp his leave party's leave was extended. He expects to go back tomorrow or Monday.

Received a letter from Charlie T- today from France & showed it to Arthur.
Entry.246:
Busy morning and afternoon also.

All the boys here got their"Aussie" mail but daresay mine will come along tomorrow 
surely
.

Big Cargo boat torpedoed a few miles out and is just about euchred at dawn.
Entry.247:
Received an Australian mail today. 16 letters. The worst is that after reading them it makes one wish more than ever that he was back in Australia.

Read 4 from Home & 3 from Joy & then went to PtSaid for a couple of hours. Returned to Hosp.; had a swim & read the rest of my mail.

At 6 pmreceived 2more letters - one from Joy & one from Mac Kirkham.
Entry.248:
Recd Reg Letter from Cpl Dones.

Busy day – Relieving on huts in afternoon.

Wrote (70) during evening.
Entry.249:
Rather a busy day all through, but wrote one or 2 letters in morning & evening.

(41) to Mother.
Entry.250:
Went to town in afternoon & got riding breeches from the tailor

Met J.A.N. Newman from the 5th L.H.Fd.Amb. who is down here on a board for the flying corps as a pilot. Expects to get through too.
Entry.251:
Busy day today.

"Jane" is being played in Pt. Said tonight in the "Eldorada Theatre".

Received parcel from Home.

Wrote some letters: Father No (28)
Entry.252:
Aust. Red Cross funds benefit by "Jane", which was a success.

Rec'd parcel from V. Forsyth (1 pr socks.)

A few letters written.
Entry.253:
Everything cleaned up for a special inspection by 
some "Base job" Colonel
.

Wrote a few letters.
Entry.254: Rather a busy day today. Missed seeing concert by "Whizz-Bangs" in the Concert Hall tonight.
Entry.255:
Things as usual.

Notified tonight that I am to hold myself in readiness to start a course of training at the N.C.O's School Moascar on Monday next. Must try & get out of this somehow. Better where I am.
Entry.256:
Did what I could to have my name off the list for the N.C.O's school but may have to go yet as it is. Am hopng for the best.

Went to Pt. Said in afternoon & on return was given a rather decent tea by the Sister in Charge of Isolation– Sister S-.

Had a swim & wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.258:
Rather a busy day and during the evening went to the concert in the Concert Hall. (Concert party of Mrs Owen's "The Optomists".)

(Am being given an exceptionally good spin at Isolation.)
Entry.259:
Warned that I am to go to the N.C.O's School at Moascar tomorrow & catch the boat at 11 am.

On leave to Pt Said & returned to Hospital in time to see the concert at 7 p.m.

("Vagabonds" Concert Party from Kantara.)

They are very good.
Entry.260:
Did a couple of my ordinary early morning jobs starting at 5.30 a.m.

Packed up kit, got into service uniform and after saying good-bye to Isolation Staff caught the Nemo at wharf (hospital) at 11 a.m.

Left wharf at 11 a.m. arriving at Port Said wharf½ hr. later. Marchedto Pt Said Rly Station and left by the 12.30 pm train arriving at Moascar siding at 2.45 p.m.

Reported to Camp O. Room & then to A.A.M.CCadre & N.C.O's School at 3.15 p.m.

Left at 4 pm. for Ismailia with Sgt Bradley. Went for swim & general look round.

Met Geo Cameron at Empire Club and with Sgt. Bradley, Sgt.Tamplin & his brother we had tea. Walked round the town & then to the Rly Staion, catching the 8.15 passenger train to Moascar siding.

(Geo Cameron is down from the Amb. for this N.C.O's school.)
Entry.261:
Reveille 4.30 a.m. Parade 5 a.m.

Breakfast 7.45 a.m. Parade 8.30 a.m.

Finish for the day at 11.30 a.m.

Wrote 2 letters. One to home & one to Joy.

Caught 2.30 p.m. goods train to Ismailia.

Spent a quiet but enjoyable afternoon and returned to camp by the 8.15 pm. from Station d'Ismailia.
Entry.262:
Routine same as yesterday.

Wrote letters after dinner.
Entry.263:
Reveille & routine as usual

After dinner wrote (74) to Joy.

Feeling tired this afternoon.

Went to concert at the Empire Soldiers Club in the Gardens in Ismailia.

Concert party from 2nd A.S.H. Staff, Moascar.

Back to camp on 9.30 p.m. from Ismailia.

A plane from the aerodrome is doing some night flying tonight over Moascar & Ismailia.
Entry.264:
Morning as usual.

Wrote a couple of letters in afternoon.

Went to concert given by "The Attractions" in the Y.M.C.A "Kitchener Hut"

At 8.30 p.m. night flying plane crashed on the flying ground.

At 9.30 pm. Reinforcements from the Pt Sydney arrived at Moascar siding. "N.Z's" & "Aussie's".

Their boat left Australia on Aug 16th so we expect to get a month's mail in a few days.
Entry.265:
As usual as regards Routine.

News of the latest movements in Palestine is in "The Egyptian Mail" today. Big advance & 3000 prisoners, guns & material.

Wrote No(74) to Joy.
Entry.266:
Routine & training as usual till 10 a.m. when we pulled ourtents down and after cleaning up the tent space disinfected both tent & ground space.

Cleaned after dinner & caught the 2 pmtrain to Ismailia. Spent a quiet afternoon & after tea at "Empire Club" went to a Cinema Show at "The Ideal"

Supper at N.Z. Club & caught 9.40 pm train from Ismailia Rly Station. On arrival at Station a Hospital train pulled in on its way to the 31st General Hosp. at Cairo. Most of the cases were wounded Majority shrapnel wounds. Got news of advance from these "Tommies". 35 miles north of original position above Jaffa & 7 miles on Nablus sector. 10,000 Jacko prisoners.

In Ismailia in afternoon met one of the "Tommies" from the 2nd Batt I.C.C. & got details of their latest stunt round Gulf of Akaba to Amman again blowing up viaduct near Rly Station.

Sunday 22 September 1918

Reveille 0600 but the planes that have been up since 4.30 a.m. gave us no chance for an hr & half extra sleep still it was a change from the previous mornings.

Went to church parade in the Y.M.C.A "Kitchener Hut" at 7 a.m.

Breakfast 0800.

Slipped for the days leave to Pt Said on acct. ofnew Routine order.

Monday 23September 1918

Reveille as usual. At 8.45 all but 14th A.G.Hchaps at the school were sent to the 2nd A.S.H. for a fortnights training.

Leave for
Entry.267:
A.G.H. chaps to attend an anniversary dinner at Port Said.

Just about to go Statn when I got my mail – 12 letters –

Caught 2 pm. train from Moascar to Port Said. Arrivedat Pt. Said at 4 p.m.

On way to Hosp. met some of the boys.

Went up to Isolation at 6 pm. and after cleaning up went to 
the
 dinner at 7.30 pm. A rather good spread. Went back to Isol. and got the gramaphone going in one of the rooms. Imshiedfrom there by M.O. & carried on out on the breakwater.

Went to bed at 10 p.m.
Entry.268:
Turned out at 5.30 a.m.

After breakfast at 6.30 
p
 a.m. caught train at Pt. Said to Moascar, arriving at Moascar siding at 10.15 a.m.

½ hrs. drill and then after dinner at 12 noon started to write (70) to Joy – 21 pages.
Entry.269:
As usual at 4.30 a.m. and on till 11.30 a.m.

Received 5 more letters today.

Wrote letters in afternoon.

Thunderstorm & dust storm arose at 5.45pmand the rain last 5 to 6 hrs. Was well needed to.
Entry.270:
Routine this morning as usual.

Went out making traverses for map reading information from 5.15 am till 7.30 a.m.

Wrote a letter or so in afternoon.
Entry.271:
Things as usual during morning.

In afternoon went to 2nd A.S.H. at Moascar.

Saw all the boys from the School.
Entry.272:
Rather a slack morning.

Struck tents after breakfast and aired ground space.

Did washing & wrote letters in afternoon.

News of Bulgarian frontier & Western front in latest wireless news.

Train loads of prisoners 
arriving
 passing daily through here.

Met Alf P- tonight.
Entry.273:
Sunday morning as usual.

Met Alf P

Going to Ismailia this afternoon for a swim.

9 p.m. Went to the baths for a swim.

Had afternoon tea at "Empire Club" & tea at N.Z. Club. Walked back to camp at 6 p.m.

The N.Z.M.R. Band played at N.Z. Club. They are very good.
Entry.274:
Parades etc. as usual.

Went to 2nd A.S.H. in afternoon with Alf P-. Saw Geo. Cameron. He has not been too good the last day or so.
Entry.275:
New Routine for time of parades comes into force.

Reveille 5 a.m. Parade 5.30 a.m.

Breakfast 
7.45
 
8 p
 8 a.m. 
B
 Parade 9.15 
p
 a.mto 11.30. Dinner 12 noon. Parade 2.30 pm. till 4.30 pm. Tea 5 p.m.

Mounted work today on all parades. Pay at 6 p.m.
Entry.276:
Routine as usual.

Good news from all fronts.

Damascus occupied.

Wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.277:
Usualroutine.

More good war news from all fronts.

Cambrai fallen. Lille surrounded. St Quentin in danger.

Recd 2 letters that have been to Engd​.
Entry.278:
Routine as usual.

At 2.30 p.m. saddled up the horses & rode to Lake Timsah. Had a swim & got some dates at at Hod½ mile away.

Received parcel from Joy through Mutual Store at 5 pm.
Entry.279:
Routine as usual.

Saddle cleaning etc.

Tents repitched.

Wrote (80).
Entry.280:
Stables etc. as usual

No church parade.
Entry.281:
Routine as per usual. Feeling rather crook today with diarrhoer.

Boys return from 2nd A.S.H.
Entry.282:
Drill & parades etc.

Swimmg. parade at 2 p.m. to L. Timsah.

Met F. Pittman on leave to Egypt to see his Father – just over from "Aussie".

F. P- has come from the old Amb. 15 mls. the other side of Damascus. Got some details of the 
C
 operations in the stunt just taking place.
Entry.283:
Parades & routine etc. as usual.

Never went on swimmg. parade. (Was asleep!)!!

Big draft of reinforcements going out to the Ambs. on Saturday –in all probability.

Word that Beirut has fallen.
Entry.284:
Routine as usual.

Wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.285:
Drill & parades etc.

Met J. A. Gould in the Cadre this morning.

Went for swimming parade to Lake Timsah.
Entry.286:
Routine as usual.

Met Thomas. O.

Wrote a couple of letters.

1914 B Class men go to Suez tonight from A details.

Accident 
at
 
aero
 with plane in the camp lines.
Entry.287:
Mail – new from "Aussie" – arrived. In first & only batch today only 2 of us at the school got mail. I got 9 letters.

Went to Ismailia on 2 p.m. train from Moascar.
Entry.288:
Received 4 letters readdressed from England & dated July.

Wrote (82) tonight.

Everywhere there is a great feeling of optimism in regards to the war ending soon.

It seems to be so any time now.
Entry.289:
Nothing startling in the way of news this morning.

Wrote 6 letters this afternoon.

Good news from all fronts continues.

Went to "Whizz Bang" concert party who are giving a show at the R.F.C. Aerodrome in this camp. They were good, too.

Wednesday 16
Entry.290:
Drill & routine as usual this morning.

Swimming parade in afternoon to Lake Timsah.

Got letter from 
Charlie
 Arthur Thompson this afternoon. He is in the 14th A.G.H. as a patient.

Saw Mr H. Thompson this morning.
Entry.291:
Routine as usual & swimming parade also in afternoon.

Wrote one or two letters.

Got letter from Charlie Thompson from France. Rumored that Mac Kirkham is killed.

Latest unofficial news from Amsterdam regarding Kaiser & the peace negotiations.
Entry.292:
Routine & parades as usual.

A big draught of reinfts are to go out in a few days and expect to go by boat to Beirut and then join up their respective units.

Wrote (83).

(Rumor of another mail in.

A boatload of "Aussie" troops is at Suez.)

(
Found to be correct
Entry.293:
.)

Saturday 19 October 1918

Nothing unusual.

Harry Thompson was along to have a yarn this afternoon.

Wrote to Charlie Thompson.

600 "Aussie" reinfts. marched into Moascar at 5.30 pm.

"Our Day" in Egypt.
Entry.294:
Reveille 6 a.m. Chruch parade at 7
p
 a.m. Went to Ismailia in afternoon.

Back to Moascar, after pictures, on the 8 p.m. train.

(Rec'd small pillow from 14th A.G.H.)
Entry.295:
Routine – morning & afternoon as usual.

A few stray letters of new mail are about.

News of Belgian coast being occupied by Allied troops by wireless from France.
Entry.296:
Examination in troop drill & signalling test also this morning. Did good, o!

Lecture by Capt. Dickinson on the Mobilisation & Discipline of the British army from outbreak of war till after battle of the 
Marne
 Aisne. (Hints on French mobilization & American.)

Wrote No (47) to Mother.

Recd 2 letters from new mail.

Put in application for Cadet School.

Wednesday 23
Entry.297:
Further tests and instruction in rifle drill.

Received my "Aussie" mail from Vic.

Wrote 84 to Joy.

Application for Cadet School turned down.
Entry.298:
Further examination, and instruction in rifles etc.

Handed (after cleaning) the rifles into the Q.M's.

Wrote (32) to Father and at 7.30 wrote out some P.CDs to send away as Xmas cards. All Xmas mail for "Aussie" has to be at Base Post Office –Kantara –by 1st Nov.

Made or rather improvised a light in the tent out of tobacco tin –piece of seam of riding breeches & some borrowed kerosene. It acted fairly well.

Wind, thunder & rain storm this afternoon. It lasted 4 hrs.
Entry.299:
Completed exam this morning.

It rained most of the day and no movement orders to hand about marching out to 14th A.G.H.

The boys who went on leave left at 9.30 a.m.

Saturday 26
Entry.300:
Drill & routine as usual till 6.45 a.m. when orders to march out came to hand.

Reported to Hd.Qrs. at 9.30 a.m. and caught 10 
p
 a.m. trainfrom Moascar to Pt. Said, arriving there at 12.15 pm.

Proceeded to Hospital and was on no duty for afternoon.

"The Vagabonds" gave a good concert in the Concert Hall tonight.
Entry.301:
Reveille 
4
6 a.m. Parade 6.30. On general duty till 8.30 a.m. Report to R.S.M. and reported for duty to Isolation Section.

A busy morning & off duty this afternoon.

Wrote (48) & (85)
Entry.302:
On general duties & runner for Isolation.

Very busy morning. Slight "cool off" in afternoon.

Wrote several letters tonight.

Strong rumors that the Austrian & Turkish armies on verge of collapse.
Entry.303:
A solid day all the time.

Hardly a minute to spare from 6 a.m. till 6.30 pm.

A convoy in this morning.
Entry.304:
Busy morning & afternoon leave.

Went to "An Mikadao" & made enquiries re the parcel that Joy never received.

Enquiries are being made at once & I will know the definite result in about 4 weeks time.

Met A.O. Stephenson today.

Alleppo occupied by Cavalry patrols & armoured cars on 26th Inst.

Received letter from "Wattie" & 5 Tkish notes from Damascus.
Entry.305:
A very busy dayall day.

At 12.35 p.m. it was announced that Turkey ceased fighting at 12 noon today. Port Said placed "Out of Bounds" to troops at 5 p.m.

Hindenbury resigned & Austria on verge of collapse.

Letter to hand from Frank Bayley.
Entry.306:
Another month started.

A very busy day today.
