Went to the concert given by "The Magpies" in the Concert Hall tonight. Rather a good program given but talent not up to "
the
" standard. (Rather rough at times)

Rec'd parcel from D'nong Patic League. It is a good parcel. Contents in good order & A1.
Entry.307:
Routine etc. as usual. Busy one way & another.

A scrap took place off the coast here this afternoon. One boat sunk on the horizon and another badly damaged towed in.

Balloon (kite) for observation purpose tested this morning out at sea.
Entry.308:
Busy as usual.

Pt. Said is out of bounds to troops after 5.30 p.m. The exact reason "WHY" we know not.
Entry.309:
A busy day throughout.

Met Tom Mahoney today.
Entry.310:
Routine etc. as usual.

Strong rumors of the Austro-Hungarian Empire's withdrawal from the war in morning & in evening confirmation of this news in the way of an Armistice, being granted to Austria by the Allies.
Entry.311: A very busy day and long hours.
Entry.312:
Busy throughout the day.

Heard that Germany "downed" arms yesterday at 6 a.m.

Received 2 letters from "Aussie" by an Eng. mail; also my "Swan" repaired came back from Mabie Todd & Co., Engd.

At 8.30 pm. news that 
Germany down
 the war ceased at 4 pm. yesterday.
Entry.313:
Busy as usual.

On leave to PtSaid during afternoon.

Got tunic from tailors' and boots (cut down) from Rest Camp "Bootmaker".
Entry.315:
Busy as ever.

Rainy and stormy weather.
Entry.316:
A terrific downpour for½ hr this morning. Evidently a monsoonal disturbance. Clothes and gear wet through.

Expect to hear of Germany having given in to peace terms by tonight, on acct. of what appeared in the cables yesterday.

Wrote of Olive this afternoon.

The "Whizz-Bangs" gave a concert tonight in the Concert Hall and during the interval "Von Kluck" announced that Germany had officially signed the Armistice with Gt Britain.

All rose and sang the "National Anthem", after which there was wild cheering.
Entry.317:
November 1918

Everyone of all nationalities went almost mad (in a sense) with delight at the news we have received.

Whistles, bells, & guns "pealed" forth to celebrate the occasion. (Will not here describe exact proceedings!).
Entry.318:
Everyone as jubilant as ever.

Wrote 89 to Joy when I ceased work for the day at 7.15p.m.
Entry.319:
Work as before.

In charge of Isolation but nothing will come of it eventually I'm sure, as I'm not one of the original 14th AGH. push.
Entry.320:
Still carrying on i/c of Isolation

Things busy too.
Entry.321:
List of latest promotions out. I'm not on the board. Orignl. 14th AGH chaps got the promotions.

Another convoy in – Sick only.
Entry.322:
Another N.C.O i/c of Isolation.

Busy as ever. Afternoon off.
Entry.324:
Routine etc. as usual.

Never ceased work till 8 p.m.
Entry.325:
On leave this afternoon with Tom Maddigan. Returned to Hosp. early to write a couple of letters – which I did.

(Got a knock back at the QM's store today.)
Entry.326:
Rather a busy day and after 7.30 p.m. till 10.45 p.m. enjoyed a 
f
 night fishing excursion along the breakwater, with several others at the invitation of the Isol. Sisters.

Got to bed after 11 pm.

Friday 22
Entry.327:
Feeling a little tired this morning after last nights excursion.

Everything as usual.
Entry.330:
Whizz-Bangs gave a concert in Concert Hall tonight. Not too bad either.

Appointt for Wed. evening altered to 
this evening
 tomorrow evening
Entry.331:
On leave this afternoon.

Got pr. of slacks and altered service breeches.

Had an enjoyable time this evening.
Entry.332:
Australian mail to hand at 6 p.m. Letters of Oct. 13th are the latest.
to

Report of Mac Kirkland being killed is confirmed in letters from home.

Started letter (91).
Entry.333:
On leave this afternoon to Pt. Said.

Rather a busy day all through.

Wrote a letter or so tonight

Friday 29
Entry.334:
On leave this afternoon to Pt. Said.

On return to Hospital was informed that I am to appear to give evidence for a District Court Martial tomorrow at 2 pm.

Did a little more writing tonight.
Entry.335:
Morning's duty & routine as usual.

On acct. of going on night duty tonight Ihave this afternoon off.

Appeared at O.R. at 2 pm. At 2.10 & 3 pm. I had to appear before Major Davidson, (Registrar) and sign a written statement in connection with the evidence for a DistCourt Martial.

On duty at 7 pmtill midnight.
Entry.336:
On duty till 7.30 a.m. Turned in to bed at 8.30 a.m. Did not sleep too well.

Hosp. rumors strong today.

On duty again at 7 p.m. till midnight.
Entry.337:
On duty till 7 a.m.

Slept from 8.15 a.m. till 1.45 pm.

Went on duty at 7 p.m. till midnight.
Entry.338:
It is now 2 a.m. and I'm not feeling too tired.

To bed at 8.30 a.m., and up again at 3 p.m.

On duty at 7 p.m. till midnight
Entry.339:
A very bleak and windy morning indeed for this country.

Wrote another letter.

Went to Port Said this afternoon, & to Rest Camp.

McK. sentenced to 28 days No 2 Field Punishment at Moascar.

He left by the Nemo. this 11 a.m.

Very hard luck for him.
Entry.340:
Slept well after going to bed at 7.45 a.m.

On duty at 7 pm. S/i Charge has put most of her job for tonight on to me. Had to sit up all night with a chap on the D.I. list.
Entry.341:
12 midnight till 7.30 a.m.

Slept fairly well today.

On again at 7 p.m. and the same stunt as last night "shoved" on to me by the S/i Charge.

Rain with bitterly cold wind in the air.
Entry.342:
Routine & hours of duty as usual.

A new Australian mail arrives at the Hospital. Afew get letters as late as Oct. 31st from W.A.

Received a parcel containing 2 silk singlets, 6 V.P.K films and Local & Daily papers from home. Sent on 25/9/18.
Entry.343:
Hours of duty as usual.

Slept well today.

At anchor in the canal at Pt Said is a boat – Huddart-Parker line – with "Aussie" soldier brides 
for
 on their way to Australia. About 400 aboard including 30 chaps A.I.F.

Chaps from here who were on leave this afternoon visited the boat and seemed to have had an enjoyable time on board.

They say that the
y
 wives were a rough looking lot, & mostly girls from 18 to 24 yrs of age.

Monday 9 December 1918

Hours of duty as usual.

At 2.30 p.m. 5 of the Isol. staff left Hosp to go to the "Zealandier" – a boat of the "Huddart-Parker line", at present anchored in the canal en route to Australia.

Were not allowed on board, so stayed in a rowing boat and "screwed" the passengers off.

Not too favorably impressed by what we saw.

Took 2 snaps of the "Zealandier".

Started to write a detailed description of the 
our
 movements of our Ambulance from the beginning of 1st stunt on Amman till our return to the Valley on April 1st and 2nd.
Entry.345:
Routine as usual.

Pessamistic opinions today regarding an early return to Australia of the A.I.F.; on account of the internal troubles in Germany.
Entry.346:
Routine as usual.

Another boat load of 800 Aust. soldiers wives from France England is expected to arrive here tonight.

(Finished the Amman stunt description.)
Entry.347:
December 1918

Hours of duty as before.

Went to Port Said this afternoon.

Wrote a few letters tonight
Entry.349:
Routine etc. as on previous days & nights.

Wrote
 An Australian mail to hand. Got 8 letters dated to 29th Oct. latest.

Wrote (94) & (53) tonight.

Party 
of 12
 go with rations by boat to 
Port
 Gallipoli Peninsula to the troops there now.

(Heard from home the rumor about Geo. Cameron's death.)A rumor only.
Entry.350:
As usual for hours of duty and routine.

Wrote a few letters tonight
Entry.351:
Things as usual 
I
 and busier that ever.

Made the acquaintance of Sister I. Borwick who is now doing N.S. duties.
Entry.352:
Hours & routine as usual.

Heard tonight that is in tomorrow's orders that I am promoted to L/Cpl.

Congrats.from N.S. & others.

Received letter from 
Thomas O. Arthur
 Thompson.

New night sister on duty tonight.
Entry.353: My promotion published in orders this morning.
Entry.354:
As usual.

Received parcel from home and 5 letters that had been to Engdon their way to Egypt from Australia.
Entry.355:
As usual.

Preparations for Xmas in the air
.

Everyone preparing for Xmas on Wednesday.

Intended to go to town but slept in this afternoon.

Walking cases (boarded) leave here for their boat to "Aussie" in a few days.

Finished No (95)
Entry.356:
Went on leave to Pt. Said this afternoon.

Ted Holder returns from Jerusalem leave
.

Sunday 22
Entry.357:
As usual for hours of routine etc.

On duty tonight on myown, with the night Sister for Isolation. A sport too.

Heard that Jim Chalmers has been killed.
Entry.358:
Went on leave to Pt Said this afternoon, & obtained my money from the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Pt Said, at 4 pm.

Met Sister M-at 4.15 pm and did Xmas shopping. Returned to hospital at 6.30 p.m.

Tuesday 24
Entry.359:
Everyone busy for tomorrow.

Hours of duty as usual.

Carol singers in rather a picturesque setting at 11.30 pm.
Entry.360:
Another Christmas Day on service abroad.

Decorations completed by 9 a.m. (To bed at 7.30 a.m.)

Got up at 12 noon and had Christmas dinner at 1 p.m. Went round all the wards between 2.30 p.m. and 4 p.m. 
Went
 At 4.30 pm went to Officers mess and got our Supper for tonight.

Tea at 5 p.m. and as elaborate a mess as was dinner.

In spite of night duty I went to the dance at 7.45 p.m. in the Concert Hall. Had a good time.

Went back to Isolation at 9.45 pm. and went on duty. Not a word said as I was not actually missed from duty.

Preparations for another "feed up" until midnight.

Officers Mess have at 13 course dinner 
mostly
 out of Regtl. funds.
Entry.361:
Supper at 12-15, with champagne & liquer to follow. The whole A1, and as good a meal as was possible.

Went to bed at 7.30 
p
a.m & dead tired.

Got up at 5 pm. & went on duty at 7 pm.

Sisters on Nursing Staff have their"Xmas dinner" tonight.

Some of Q.M's Dept leave for Cairo.
Entry.362:
Staff Christmas Dinner for Cpls, L/Cpl's & Ptes. today, but I never troubled to get up at mdday.

but
 Went to Pt Said at 4 p.m. to tailors.

Wrote a number of letters tonight.
Entry.363:
To Port Said in afternoon

350 Patients and 30 Sisters are to leave tomorrow morning for Cairo. They will go by boat to Pt Said, motor ambulance to Rly Station and be entrained 
by
 (in a Hosp. train) to Cairo; thence to Abbasia.
Entry.365:
Night duty hours of duty same as before

Hasty preparations for al to leave for Cairo in a day or so.
Entry.366:
On General Duties tonight as all Isol. patients have been removed

A busy day & a quiet New Year's Eve.

At Midnight all sirens & whistles from boats in the canal started & kept going for¼ hr or so.
